messageBody:
Welcome to the world of CLASSPATH ... One of the less elegant aspects of Java development.

The issue that you are dealing with here is that there are two kinds of references that you can have in a CLASSPATH. The first is a JAR file and the second is a directory. Unfortunately, a JAR file in a directory on the CLASSPATH does not get searched (I know, I know, it's silly, but we have to live with it). So to address your question, you will need to include both the reference to the Junit JAR file and the directory where the samples live. eg:

CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1/junit.jar:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1
export CLASSPATH

This will get you to the next step, but it does sound like you need to learn a little more about the shell, (http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/ is a good programming guide to the bash shell).

Also, I strongly suggest switching to ant (http://ant.apache.org/) for your compile/build process. It isn't perfect, but it does 99% of most everything that I need, and I code in Java for a living. It will also help with CLASSPATH issues.

Consider switching to a CLASSPATH of ".", yes that is just the current directory and then using the <path> facilities for individual projects.

Anyway, this might have been more than you wanted, but I hope that something in the above helps.

Feel free to contact me directly if you want more help, or we can continue to work through the mailing list so that others can be helped. :-)

Simon
